summary: This document is a chain of email correspondence from 2019-2020 between U.S. Attorney's Office personnel, requesting and approving travel for the team investigating the 'United States v. Epstein' case (2018R01618). The emails detail planned trips to Los Angeles, West Palm Beach, Fort Lauderdale, and Stockholm, Sweden, for victim interviews and meetings, often requesting hotel conference rooms for the interviews.

connections.description: Both are members of the Epstein investigation team, with S requesting travel for themselves and M for interviews.

events.title: LA Interview Conference
events.description: The investigation team plans to use a hotel conference room in Los Angeles for an interview related to the Epstein case.

events.title: Stockholm Interview
events.description: The investigation team requests travel to Stockholm, Sweden, for an interview, indicating the international scope of the Epstein investigation.

events.title: West Palm Beach Interview
events.description: S and another team member plan to travel to West Palm Beach, Florida, for an interview, requesting a hotel conference room.

events.title: LA Victim Interview
events.description: The team requests travel to Los Angeles for a victim interview, with S, M, and/or another member as travelers.

events.title: Florida Meetings and Interviews
events.description: The team requests travel to West Palm Beach for meetings and interviews with victims, with the composition of the team (S and M or others) dependent on scheduling.

keyFacts: The document references the ongoing federal investigation 'United States v. Epstein, 2018R01618', described as 'an investigation relating to enticement of minors for sexual activity'.
The investigation involved international travel, with a planned interview in Stockholm, Sweden, in January 2020.
Multiple trips to Los Angeles and West Palm Beach/Fort Lauderdale, Florida, were conducted throughout 2019 and early 2020 specifically for victim interviews.
The team routinely requested hotel conference rooms to conduct these interviews.
The correspondence shows a pattern of internal travel approval requests within the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York for this case.
